results.title: Bike ed in action; be seen to be safe.
results.creator_credit: Materials production, Education Dept, Bike Ed, Ivan Gaal, David Ferris, Mark Laughlin and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: This compilation tape consists of two programs covering various aspects of bicycle safety. “Bike ed in action” highlights the alarming accident rate among Victorian cyclists and reviews the Bike Education Curriculum Unit which aims to develop positive cycling safety skills. Basic cycling safety measures are demonstrated. “Be seen to be safe” looks at some of the precautions young cyclists must take to ensure that they are seen at night.
results.title_for_label: Bike ed in action; be seen to be safe.

results.title: Bijan
results.creator_credit: Bruce Moir, Chris Noonan and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours: India”.
A personal look at the life of Bijan Choudhury, an artist who lives in a village close to Calcutta. Through his paintings we gain an inside impression of Calcutta and the differences between living in a city and living in a quiet village. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Bighorn!
results.creator_credit: Eleanor Riger, Tomorrow Entertainment and Robert Riger
results.brief_description: Hosted by John Denver, this program considers the habitat and behavior of the Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep and shows how the lives of the sheep are being threatened by the activities of man. Denver speaks and sings of the oneness with the world he feels during his trip through the mountains and of how people must relearn to respect nature, her laws and inhabitants. The trip covers the period from early spring through winter, and many animals are glimpsed and discussed. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Bigger, faster, stronger
results.creator_credit: W O. Whitaker, Brigham Young University and Scott Whitaker
results.brief_description: Narrated by world discus thrower, L. Jay Sylvester, tells how weight training is used to produce bigger, faster, stronger athletes. Features championship high school, college and professional athletes, and shows that sucess in athletics come only to who make a real commitment.

results.title: Bigger than Texas
results.creator_credit: Hugh Burton, Victorian College of the Arts and Mark Pugh
results.brief_description: During a bank hold-up the robber and one of his victims strike up an unlikely rapport. An ‘almost’ love story about the chance meeting of two misfits in search of escape routes from their sordid lives. The music and Pugh’s photography propel these intriguing characters through a world of surreal suspense.

results.title: Big town (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Cyclops Films, Michael Bortman, Eliot Noyes and Claudia Weill
results.brief_description: Presents five vignettes about life in and around New York City. “Mannequin” - by Michael Bortman - preparation for a mannequin parade. “Marriage” - a city marriage; “Commuters” - early morning commuters; “Yoga” - a yoga group; “Lost and Found” - the little losses that loom large to the people of the big city - by Elliot Noyes, Jr and Claudia Weill.

results.title: Big people, little people
results.brief_description: A big city is inhabited only by Little People (children) who do all the things Big People usually do - as policemen, train drivers, postmen, builders, housewives - but this leaves the play-grounds empty. However, the mayor is wise and sends for some Big People to take over the work of the city.

results.title: Big nose: Takeshi Hoshino with the Tasmanian Puppet Theatre
results.brief_description: This film explores the concept of puppetry as an art form as it goes backstage at the Tasmanian Puppet Theatre. Takeshi Hoshino, art director from Japan’s Puk Theatre designs and directs the production of “Big Nose”, a traditional Japanese story. Suitable for years prep-6 and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Big night out
results.brief_description: Wilbur Wilde and Kerry Simpson feature in this rap cartoon addressing the importance of not sharing needles and how to correctly clean them. Using animated and studio footage the story revolves around a party where the issue of safe needle use arises. “Big Night Out” provides safe use messages (ie: cleaning injecting equipment effectively and where to get new needles and syringes) via the Streetwise cartoon character, Dr Klevadik. The language utilised within the video is “street based” in order to increase target group acceptance. Aims to provide safe messages regarding intravenous drug use and potential HIV and HepB transmission.
